Title: CURRICULUM FOR FATHERS: HEALTHY FAMILIES, STRONG COMMUNITIES
Summary:
Summary of the Source
This document is the Curriculum for Fathers, jointly developed by Equimundo and SEED Foundation, with support from the United States Department of State. It is an innovative program that centers a family approach to healthy relationships, gender norms, and positive parenting techniques. The curriculum has been specifically adapted for the context of the Kurdistan Region of Iraq (KRI) in 2022.
Target Audience and Goals
The curriculum is intended to be facilitated to fathers with adolescent sons aged 15-19. Although separate fathers' and sons’ curricula exist, the overall program aims to engage both groups to reduce intergenerational violence and foster caring and supportive relationships within the family. The program is implemented in KRI, engaging Kurdish host community members, Iraqi internally displaced persons (IDPs), and the Syrian refugee population. It is adapted from Program H, which focuses on engaging youth in critical reflections on gender and helping them build skills for more empowered and equitable ways of acting.
Curriculum Structure and Key Themes
The curriculum consists of ten sessions, each designed with specific objectives, activities, discussion questions, and a weekly commitment for participants to apply lessons in their daily lives.
Key themes covered across the sessions include:
• Gender and Roles: Understanding the influence of male authority figures, discussing the difference between sex and gender, reflecting on gender norms, and exploring attitudes about men’s and women’s roles in the home and society (Session 2).
• Emotions and Conflict: Helping participants identify anger and express it nonviolently, discussing the difficulties men face in expressing emotions, and practicing nonviolent conflict resolution techniques (Sessions 3, 6).
• Violence and Power: Identifying different types of violence (physical, emotional, sexual, social, economic), discussing the link between past experiences of violence and the violence one inflicts on others, increasing awareness of power dynamics in relationships, and discussing the advantages of equitable decision-making (Sessions 4, 5).
• Honor Violence: Critically examining honor killings and honor-based violence, how they relate to masculinity, and exploring ways to challenge these harmful norms within families and the community (Session 7).
• Family Communication and Vision: Reflecting on the importance of communication and affection, developing effective communication skills between parents and young people (Session 8, sometimes facilitated with fathers and sons together), and crafting a shared family vision and long-term goals (Session 8).
• Positive Parenting: Making connections between parenting goals and how harsh discipline affects them, and providing fathers with positive parenting techniques, including giving praise and expressing love (Session 9).
• Sustaining Change: Reflecting on positive changes made and preparing family action plans to sustain and reinforce these changes (Session 10).
Facilitation Approach
Facilitators are instructed to act as guides, promoting reflection and participatory learning rather than lecturing. They are advised to use process questions that encourage deeper thought, create a safe and respectful environment, and be prepared to address sensitive and complex topics, including having resources available for referrals to professional services like counseling.

Title: CURRICULUM FOR YOUTH: HEALTHY FAMILIES, STRONG COMMUNITIES
Summary:
Summary of the Source
This document outlines a detailed curriculum intended for adolescent boys aged 15-19, jointly developed by Equimundo and The SEED Foundation, with support from the United States Department of State. The curriculum has been specifically adapted for the context of the Kurdistan Region of Iraq (KRI) in 2022.
Program Goals and Audience
The innovative program centers a family approach to gender norms, healthy relationships, and positive parenting techniques. Although this is a separate curriculum designed for young men, the overall program engages with both fathers and their adolescent sons to reduce intergenerational violence and foster healthy, caring, and supportive family relationships. The program aims to sensitize young men to harmful socialization patterns and help them act in more empowered and equitable ways. Participants include Kurdish host community members, Iraqi internally displaced persons (IDPs), and the Syrian refugee population in KRI.
Curriculum Structure and Key Themes
The curriculum consists of nine core sessions (plus an alternative session). Each session follows a standardized format, including objectives, key activities, suggested timing, required materials, key messages, and group discussion questions.
Key thematic areas explored across the sessions include:
• Masculinity and Gender Roles (Session 1): Sessions introduce participants to the group, establish a safe environment, and encourage them to understand the impact and costs of rigid forms of masculinity and gender roles on men's and women's lives.
• Family Influence and History (Session 2): Participants reflect on the influence of fathers, mothers, and other authority figures, seeking to replicate positive aspects while addressing negative patterns.
• Power Dynamics (Session 3): The curriculum addresses how factors such as gender, race, ethnicity, and other characteristics influence how much power individuals have in society, and how that power can restrict their progress. The concept of "power over" systems, including patriarchy, is discussed.
• Violence and Emotions (Sessions 4 & 5): Participants identify different types of violence (physical, emotional, sexual, social, and economic). The curriculum treats violence as a learned behavior that is not innate, meaning it can be eliminated. Participants are encouraged to identify ways they can express anger through nonviolent means, recognizing that anger is a natural emotion but violence is a behavior.
• Relationships and Intervention (Sessions 6 & 7): Sessions focus on naming characteristics of healthy and unhealthy relationships and practicing bystander intervention to safely and effectively prevent and interrupt sexist behaviors, violence, and conflict in the community.
• Communication and Future Goals (Sessions 8 & 9): Session 8 focuses on the importance of communication and affection, sometimes facilitated with sons and fathers together. The final session helps young men reflect on their identities, construct life plans, prepare for possible obstacles, and appreciate the positive changes they have made.
Facilitator Guidance
Facilitators are instructed to act as guides, not teachers. Their role is to promote reflection and participatory learning in a safe, non-judgmental environment. Due to the sensitive and complex themes, facilitators must be prepared to address issues like sexual trauma, understand their agency's mandatory reporting requirements, and have a list of professional services (like counseling) for referrals. A key tool used to foster change is the Weekly Commitment, a specific task participants take on to incorporate lessons into their daily lives.

Title: BRIEF 1. Parenting programmes to reduce violence against children and women: Why it is important
Summary:
Summary of the Source
This document, Brief 1, argues that parenting and caregiver support programmes are in a unique position to reduce violence within the family, specifically violence against children (VAC) and violence against their mothers or female caregivers (VAW).
Context and Focus
The brief was developed by UNICEF Innocenti, Prevention Collaborative, and Equimundo. It is intended for practitioners implementing parenting programs. The series intentionally highlights parenting programmes because they are already reaching parents and caregivers in many communities and can be strengthened to reduce violence and promote gender equality.
The brief focuses on the most common forms of violence that often co-occur in families: violent discipline by parents (VAC) and intimate partner violence (IPV) (VAW). Globally, three-quarters of children ages 2 to 4 experience violent discipline, and a third of women experience physical or sexual violence from a partner in their lifetime. The information primarily relates to programs for parents of young children but is applicable to parents of older children and adolescents as well.
Core Arguments for Intersectionality
The brief details why addressing both forms of violence simultaneously is crucial:
1. Compounded Negative Consequences: Both violent discipline and IPV are associated with negative impacts on children's health, development, and well-being. Exposure to violence can affect a child’s developing brain, leading to difficulties such as poor impulse control or aggression later in life. These negative impacts are compounded when children are exposed to multiple types of violence.
2. Intergenerational Cycle: Violence has long-term and intergenerational consequences. Children in violent homes may learn that violence is a normal way to resolve conflict, increasing their risk of becoming a perpetrator (for men) or a victim (for women) of violence in adulthood or of using violence against their own children.
3. Shared Risk Factors: VAC and VAW share common social and family risk factors, most significantly being rooted in gender inequality. Common social norms sustaining both forms of violence include those that support gender inequality, promote harmful masculinities based on violence and control, and condone the violent discipline of children and women.
4. Program Effectiveness: Failing to address both VAC and VAW is a missed opportunity, potentially undermining the desired outcomes of parenting programs. Emerging evidence suggests that parenting programs can reduce both VAC and VAW simultaneously, even if they were not explicitly designed to do so.
Gender-Transformative Approach
The brief champions a gender-transformative approach for parenting programs. These programs intentionally seek to address the root causes of gender-based inequalities and challenge harmful gender roles, norms, and power imbalances.
Gender-transformative programs work with both female and male parents and caregivers to:
• Promote critical reflection and discussion of unequal gender attitudes.
• Help parents identify the benefits of more equitable ways of being.
• Strengthen relationship and parenting skills (e.g., conflict resolution, emotional self-regulation, and nonviolent discipline).
• Increase men's participation in childcare and household tasks.
• Promote equitable relationships where partners share responsibility and power in decision-making.

Title: BRIEF 2. Parenting programmes to reduce violence against children and women: What gender-transformative programmes look like
Summary:
Summary of the Source
This document, Brief 2, is the second in a series designed to provide parenting practitioners with evidence-based insights to support the adaptation and strengthening of existing parenting programmes. Its central focus is exploring the practical elements—principles, delivery characteristics, and content—of gender-transformative parenting programmes (GTPPs) that effectively reduce violence in the family.
Rationale and Gender-Transformative Approach
Parenting programmes are in a unique position to reduce violence against children (VAC) (specifically violent discipline) and violence against women (VAW) (specifically intimate partner violence, or IPV) because these types of violence often co-occur and share common risk factors rooted in gender inequality.
GTPPs are defined as those that intentionally seek to address and challenge the root causes of gender-based inequalities and harmful gender roles, norms, and power imbalances. They work with both female and male parents and caregivers to promote more caring, equitable, and nonviolent family dynamics. These programs aim to transform parents' gender attitudes and behaviors, improve couple relations, and build essential skills like communication, emotional self-regulation, conflict resolution, and nonviolent discipline.
Common Principles and Delivery Features
Effective GTPPs share several guiding principles:
• Gender Equality: They are grounded in women’s rights and promote gender equality as both a goal and a pathway to violence prevention.
• Engaging Men: They explicitly engage men as equitable parents and caregivers, recognizing men are the primary perpetrators of IPV and that unequal relationship dynamics are risk factors for both VAC and VAW. Programs appeal to men positively, focusing on their desire to be better parents.
• Community Involvement: They engage communities, including parents, children, and stakeholders, early in the design or adaptation process to ensure relevance, obtain buy-in, and mitigate potential backlash.
• Strengths-Based Approach: Programs do not focus on telling parents they are failing but highlight the benefits of participation, such as achieving happier, more peaceful families and stronger relationships.
• Safety and Rights: They prioritize women’s and children’s safety by developing adequate safeguarding policies, monitoring implementation, and providing referrals to support services.
In terms of delivery, GTPPs:
• Use structured curricula with at least 10 regular sessions, based on theories of change that allow time for reflection and practice (often through a Weekly Commitment).
• Train peer or community-based facilitators (often including male facilitators to appeal to men) who receive adequate training on gender norms and referral services.
• Combine single-sex sessions (for open discussion) with mixed-sex sessions (couples’ sessions) to foster communication and shared aspirations.
• Use participatory approaches (e.g., group discussion, role-play) rather than lecturing, fostering a safe and supportive environment for critical reflection.
Core Curriculum Content
The content of GTPPs commonly includes activities designed to:
• Promote reflection on gender norms and power imbalances and the costs of adhering to inequitable norms.
• Raise awareness of violence (including its manifestation and consequences) and how social norms justify it.
• Build couple relationship skills like communication, active listening, and conflict resolution, including discussions about sharing household decisions and responsibilities.
• Strengthen positive parenting skills, emphasizing emotional closeness, responsive care, and nonviolent techniques for managing children’s behavior.
• Build parents’ skills to manage strong emotions like anger or frustration to reduce the risk of using violence.
• Promote more equitable family dynamics, specifically men’s equal participation in childcare and household tasks.
• Encourage reflection on participants' own childhoods to break harmful intergenerational patterns.
• Promote positive gender socialization to support raising children free from gender stereotypes.
• Address responsible relationships with alcohol, a known risk factor for violence.
• Foster family, peer, and community support to enable and sustain behavior change.

Title: BRIEF 3. Parenting programmes to reduce violence against children and women: How to adapt programmes to address both types of violence
Summary:
Summary of the Source
This document, Brief 3, is the third in a series providing guidance to parenting practitioners who want to strengthen or adapt their existing parenting programs to integrate violence prevention and gender equality. The guidance focuses on tackling the most common forms of violence that often co-occur in families: violent discipline (Violence Against Children, or VAC) and intimate partner violence (IPV) (Violence Against Women, or VAW).
Gender-Transformative Approach and Goals
The brief is based on the premise that effective programs take a gender-transformative approach, meaning they intentionally challenge unequal gender norms and power dynamics to promote more equitable, caring, and nonviolent family dynamics. These adaptations aim to transform parents' gender attitudes, improve couple relations, and build essential skills like communication, emotional self-regulation, conflict resolution, and nonviolent discipline. This process is intended to unlock parents' potential to provide care and raise their children free from gender stereotypes.
The Five Stages of Adaptation
The core of the brief proposes an iterative and participatory approach organized into five stages, designed to guide practitioners through the adaptation process:
1. Gain organisational and stakeholder buy-in: This initial stage requires securing sufficient time and resources. Practitioners must get staff and management on board, especially regarding integrating violence prevention and engaging men. It also involves engaging external actors (like women’s organizations or government representatives) and identifying, mitigating, and monitoring potential backlash or risks (e.g., increased violence) that challenging deeply entrenched gender norms may create for participants.
2. Consult parents and understand gender and violence in your context: This stage requires consulting existing research on the prevalence and drivers of VAC and VAW and conducting formative research with parents, children (where feasible), and community leaders. Consultation is necessary to identify local norms, understand barriers to participation (like work schedules or childcare needs), and explore opportunities and strategies for engaging fathers.
3. Adapt your programme recruitment, content, and design: This involves three major areas:
    ◦ Content: Integrating critical reflection on gender and power dynamics throughout the curriculum, raising awareness of different types of violence, and discussing how violence undermines family relationships and goals. Content should be strengthened with skill-building activities in couple communication, conflict resolution, and positive parenting practices.
    ◦ Session Format: Deciding whether to use single-sex or mixed-sex/couples' sessions, based on context, participant preference, and potential risks, recognizing that separate sessions might be safer for sensitive topics like IPV or alcohol abuse.
    ◦ Recruitment: Revising messaging to resonate with and clearly invite both mothers and fathers/couples.
4. Test and refine your adapted programme: Practitioners must test revised recruitment strategies and messaging, and pilot the full curriculum with a small group of parents or facilitators before a full rollout.
5. Train and adequately support facilitators to successfully implement: This final stage involves assessing facilitator capacity, potentially including (more) male facilitators to work with fathers, and providing sufficient training (often 10 days) on the program rationale and sensitive issues like gender norms and violence. Crucially, clear referral processes to support services must be designed, and facilitators must receive supportive supervision, check-ins on their well-being, and guidance on navigating disclosures of violence. Session timing and locations must be accessible for participants, even if outside regular working hours.

Title: BRIEF 4. Parenting programmes to reduce violence against children and women: How to measure change
Summary:
Summary of the Source
This document, Brief 4, is a guide for parenting practitioners on how to effectively monitor and evaluate (M&E) their programs after they have been adapted to integrate gender equality and violence prevention. The brief focuses on measuring change related to violent discipline (Violence Against Children, VAC) and intimate partner violence (IPV) (Violence Against Women, VAW), which often co-occur and share risk factors rooted in unequal gender norms and power dynamics.
Monitoring (M) Emphasis and Risks
Monitoring is defined as the systematic process of collecting, analyzing, and using information to track progress and make "real-time" changes. The brief stresses that monitoring is critical immediately following program adaptation to ensure that modifications—which take a gender-transformative approach—are implemented as intended.
The brief outlines eight key domains for monitoring implementation:
1. Staff and Facilitator Training and Support: Assessing whether staff are equipped with the necessary knowledge and confidence to implement gender-transformative content.
2. Impact on Staff/Facilitators: Measuring changes in facilitators' own attitudes about gender and violence, as well as monitoring their well-being, stress, and potential backlash.
3. Reach, Attendance, and Retention: Tracking how many participants (disaggregated by sex/gender identity) attend and complete the program, especially noting challenges in engaging men.
4. Implementation Quality and Fidelity: Ensuring that facilitators adhere to the curriculum content, key messaging on gender equality, and the core gender-transformative principles.
5. Acceptability and Resonance: Gathering feedback from participants and community stakeholders on how the adapted program is perceived.
6. Referral to Additional Services: Tracking how many participants are referred to support services (e.g., legal, health, psychosocial) and whether the referral pathways are functioning.
7. Mandatory Reporting Obligations: Tracking reports made to authorities and assessing any potential consequences or negative impacts on children or female caregivers.
8. Potential Risks and Unintended Consequences: Actively monitoring for adverse events, such as increased violence or community backlash, and documenting risk mitigation strategies.
Evaluation (E) and Ethical Considerations
Evaluation systematically assesses the program's impact, usually by comparing outcomes over time or between groups. For effective evaluation, plans must align with the program's theory of change, and data should be disaggregated by sex or gender identity.
Qualitative research (e.g., in-depth interviews) is highly recommended alongside quantitative data to illuminate the mechanisms of change and explore why certain outcomes were or were not achieved.
The brief emphasizes that researching VAC and VAW carries unique ethical and safety challenges, requiring practitioners to prioritize participant safety and follow international ethical guidelines. Data collectors must be specially trained on gender, violence, confidentiality, referral processes, and how to manage distress and potential vicarious trauma.
Key Outcomes to Measure
To assess the impact of gender-transformative adaptations, the brief highlights several key outcomes practitioners should measure, using validated tools where possible:
• Attitudes: Changes in attitudes about gender roles, the division of household tasks, the acceptance of IPV, and the physical punishment of children.
• Violence Perpetration/Experience: Reductions in VAC perpetration (e.g., using MICS discipline module) and IPV experience or perpetration (e.g., using WHO Multi-Country Study items).
• Couple Relations: Improvements in the frequency and quality of couple communication and relationship closeness, as well as co-parenting relations.
• Power Dynamics: Shifts toward more equitable decision-making and a more equitable division of labor (increasing men's participation in childcare and household tasks).
• Shared Risk Factors: Changes in factors that drive violence, such as caregiver mental health (depression/anxiety) and alcohol consumption.

Title: Creating Peace: A Curriculum Promoting Healing, Nonviolence, Racial Justice, and Gender Equity Among Adolescents
Summary:
Summary of the Source
The Creating Peace curriculum is a detailed, gender-transformative methodology designed primarily for high school-age youth of all genders, ranging from the ages 14 to 19. It is anchored in an intersectional feminist approach that recognizes that systems of power impact the most marginalized members of society.
Core Philosophy and Origin
The curriculum is a rare example of an approach from the Global South informing and inspiring approaches in the Global North. It was specifically inspired by similar curricula from the Living Peace Institute in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), where Equimundo has partnered for years. The approach emerged as a critique of individualistic violence prevention efforts, emphasizing that while individual support (like counseling) is necessary, healing from trauma and violence is also a collective effort.
The curriculum is rooted in understanding how gender norms (such as expecting boys to "play through the pain" or girls to "put up with certain forms of violence") affect trauma recovery and contribute to violence perpetration. It recognizes that young people are not only victims of trauma but are also agents of change, uniquely positioned to be part of solutions and community transformation. The curriculum development included input from community members in the Pittsburgh region.
Goals and Intervention Components
The overarching goal is to decrease violence perpetration among the target population. This is achieved through five main objectives:
1. Establishing a safe space for addressing and healing from violence.
2. Promoting gender equity, positive relationship norms, and nonviolent attitudes.
3. Practicing positive relationship-building and bystander skills.
4. Building leadership skills to address racial and gender injustice nonviolently.
5. Engaging in ** community-based activism**.
The content specifically focuses on the relationships among gender inequity, racial injustice, and violence perpetration.
Structure and Themes
The curriculum is organized into 12 sessions, generally following the socio-ecological model (moving from individual reflection to interpersonal relationships and, finally, to community action). Sessions are structured with objectives, procedures, and group discussions. Core themes addressed include:
• Self-Identity: Defining sex assigned at birth, gender identity, gender expression, and sexual orientation (Session 3).
• Emotions and Power: Exploring emotions, identifying how gender can make expressing emotions difficult (Session 4), and understanding power imbalances (Session 5).
• Relationships and Violence: Discussing healthy/unhealthy relationships, sexual consent (Session 6), and identifying forms of violence (physical, emotional, sexual, economic).
• Action and Community: Developing safe and effective bystander intervention techniques (Session 7), reflecting on future orientation and community goals (Session 8), and planning and executing a youth-led community organizing and activism event (Sessions 9, 10, 11).
Facilitation Approach
Facilitators are positioned as guides, not teachers. They must embrace a trauma-sensitive approach, prioritizing principles such as safety, trustworthiness, and empowerment. Crucially, facilitators must inform minor participants about mandatory reporting requirements for disclosures of abuse or harm. The curriculum also includes guidelines for adaptation, implementation, monitoring, and evaluation, with specific support for virtual delivery models.

Title: Program ABB-Early Childhood Development – A manual Promoting Positive Parenting and Strengthening Active Father’s Involvement in Early Childhood Development
Summary:
This document is the manual for Program ABB-Early Childhood Development (Program P-ECD), an initiative jointly developed by Equimundo and the ABAAD Organization. The Ministry of Social Affairs (MoSA) in Lebanon adopted this program and plans to integrate it into its basket of social services at the national level.
Core Goals and Audience
The program is a gender-transformative methodology designed to be a flexible, scientific, and practical guide suited for the Lebanese cultural environment. Its overall goal is to enhance the role of fathers, making the Arabic term 'Abb' (father) synonymous with active, caring, and equal parenting.
The program targets male caregivers and couples (fathers and their partners) with a focus on children between the ages of 0 and 8 years. It specifically addresses the needs of vulnerable populations, including Syrian refugees residing in Lebanon, whose experiences of conflict and displacement have altered household dynamics and increased rates of domestic violence.
The curriculum seeks to challenge the severe global and local gender gap in unpaid care work, where women still spend significantly more time on housework and caregiving than men. The program advocates that when men take on a more equal role in the home, it strengthens women's empowerment and independence, and improves the health and well-being of the entire family.
Structure and Methodology
The manual contains thirteen basic group educational sessions and two supplementary sessions. Group education sessions are typically 1 to 2 hours long.
The methodology is rooted in gender consciousness (conscientization), encouraging participants to critically reflect on the history of cultural conditions and gender norms. It uses the Socio-Ecological Model to highlight that sustainable change requires interventions at the individual, relational, community, and societal levels. Effective implementation involves combining group education with youth-led campaigns, activism, and advocacy to influence public policies.
Key thematic areas explored in the sessions include:
• Gender and Masculinities: Examining individual attitudes, roles, double standards, and how restrictive gender norms (Man Box) affect men's emotional expression and relationships.
• Caregiving Roles: Reflecting on the intergenerational transmission of caregiving, comparing the daily routines of men and women to highlight disparities, and defining positive qualities in the Human Box that should apply to all parents regardless of gender.
• Power and Violence: Analyzing power dynamics in relationships, discussing the devaluation of housework, defining the cycle of violence, and practicing non-violent conflict resolution. Violence is presented as a learned behavior that can be unlearned.
• Positive Parenting and ECD: Establishing long-term parenting goals, promoting empathy by understanding stages of child development (0–3 years), learning to give specific praise, and using constructive consequences through positive parenting techniques.
• Support Systems: Encouraging men to build and rely on support networks, which is crucial as men are often socialized to be self-sufficient and never seek help.
Facilitators are positioned as guides, not teachers, whose role is to create a safe space, promote inclusion, manage time, and model equitable relationships if co-facilitating. Due to the sensitive nature of the topics, facilitators must be knowledgeable about referral services for psychosocial and trauma-focused support.

Title: CORE ELEMENTS OF GENDER-TRANSFORMATIVE FATHERHOOD PROGRAMS TO PROMOTE CARE EQUALITY AND PREVENT VIOLENCE
Summary:
Summary of the Source
This document is a systematic review and learning brief developed by Equimundo that consolidates evidence and practice-based knowledge from various adaptations of Program P around the world. Program P ("P" for father in Portuguese and Spanish) was initially developed in 2011 as part of the MenCare campaign to promote men's positive involvement in fatherhood, caregiving, and maternal, newborn, and child health (MNCH).
Methodology and Scope
The review drew on a rich body of evaluation research and practice-based knowledge from partners globally. The findings are primarily synthesized from eight rigorous case studies of Program P adaptations implemented in 12 countries across Africa, Latin America, the Middle East, Europe, and South Asia. The brief focuses specifically on the gender-transformative group education component of Program P for men and their partners, which is the central and most frequently evaluated part of the program.
Core Program Philosophy and Goals
Program P is a gender-transformative fatherhood program that aims to improve family well-being, strengthen couple relationships, and address the global gender gap in unpaid care work [6 P adaptations implemented in 12 countries across Africa, Latin America, the Middle East, Europe, and South Asia. The brief focuses specifically on the gender-transformative group education component of Program P for men and their partners, which is the central and most frequently evaluated part of the program.
Core Program Philosophy and Goals
Program P is a gender-transformative fatherhood program that aims to improve family well-being, strengthen couple relationships, and address the global gender gap in unpaid care work. The methodology is experiential and participatory, encouraging male caregivers and their partners to critically reflect on restrictive gender norms and power dynamics that contribute to violence. The ultimate goal is to reduce the intergenerational transmission of violence by promoting equitable and nonviolent attitudes and behaviors.
Key Evidence and Impact Areas
The review finds that Program P adaptations have significant potential to reduce violence and promote equitable family dynamics:
• Gender Attitudes and Norms: All eight programs demonstrated positive shifts in men’s and women’s gender attitudes, including greater awareness of the domestic burden on women and decreased endorsement of violence as a means to gain respect.
• Intimate Partner Violence (IPV): Evidence suggests Program P adaptations have potential to reduce women’s experiences of IPV from their male partners. Two programs rigorously evaluated with Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs) (Bandebereho in Rwanda and Program P Bolivia) found statistically significant reductions in at least one form of IPV (physical, sexual, emotional, economic, or psychological).
• Violence Against Children (VAC) and Parenting: Three of the four programs that measured VAC prevalence found reductions in the use of physical punishment of children. The programs also showed promising evidence in increasing the use of positive parenting practices (e.g., explaining misbehavior, redirecting attention).
• Caregiving and Domestic Work: Six of the seven programs that measured men's participation reported positive changes, showing men increased their time spent on household and childcare tasks, though gendered roles often persisted.
• Couple Relations: Two RCTs found statistically significant evidence of increased joint decision-making and multiple programs reported improved couple communication and emotional support.
• MNCH/SRH: Programs successfully shifted men's attitudes toward and increased their participation in supporting MNCH, leading to increased women's attendance at antenatal care visits and greater use of modern contraception.
Core Components for Effective Implementation
The brief identifies six essential components necessary for achieving sustained impact and policy influence:
1. Partnerships: Developing balanced, long-term partnerships with organizations committed to gender justice principles.
2. Alliances: Fostering strong alliances with government, health, and other sectors to catalyze collective efforts and achieve policy-level changes.
3. Methodology: Committing to a contextualized, engaging, and experiential methodology based on social learning and centered on equitable couple relations and men’s caregiving. This includes conducting formative research and piloting the curriculum.
4. Facilitation: Planning adequate time and resources (ideally seven to ten days of initial training) to recruit, train, and support local facilitators who can promote critical reflection.
5. Enabling Environment: Creating a supportive environment by engaging institutions, service providers, and community structures.
6. Funding: Securing flexible, long-term funding to support quality partnerships and adaptive programming.

Title: Many Ways of Being: An inclusive, youth-centered curriculum focused on gender equity, healthy relationships, and safer sex practices
Summary:
Summary of the Source
The Many Ways of Being (MWB) curriculum is an eight-session (16-hour) program designed for young people of all gender identities, ages 15 to 19. While adaptable, it was initially developed based on formative research with Black and Latinx youth and is primarily intended for implementation with youth of color in Washington, DC.
Core Goals and Approach
The program is grounded in gender-transformative approaches, meaning it aims to transform unequal gender roles, norms, and power relations to promote more equitable outcomes and constructive roles for people of all genders. The ultimate goals are to reduce the incidence of sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and unplanned pregnancy, and to promote healthy, consensual, and violence-free relationships among youth.
The methodology is also described as medically accurate, trauma-informed, sex-positive, and culturally responsive. The curriculum's development was informed by Equimundo's earlier single-sex curricula, Manhood 2.0 and Sisterhood 2.0, which were U.S. adaptations of Program H and Program M. A key adaptation in MWB was combining genders in sessions to reflect the desire for gender-synchronous implementation and emphasize that there are indeed "many ways of being". The content consistently pushes beyond the gender binary and heteronormative relationships.
Key Curriculum Content (Sessions 1–8)
The curriculum is organized into sessions that focus on identity, emotion, relationships, sexual health, and future planning:
• Identity and Gender (Session 2): Participants explore the concepts of sex assigned at birth, gender identity, gender expression, and sexual orientation, discussing the restrictive nature and consequences of rigid forms of masculinity and femininity (the "Man Box" and "Woman Box"). The curriculum incorporates an intersectional lens, probing how race, ethnicity, and wealth impact lived experiences.
• Emotions and Conflict (Session 3): Sessions address the impact of gendered expectations on expressing emotions, teach healthy coping strategies for difficult emotions (like anger), and develop effective communication skills using "I" statements in conflict resolution.
• Power and Relationships (Session 4): Participants define healthy and unhealthy relationships and explore how unequal power dynamics can lead to various forms of violence. The session concludes with developing strategies for setting boundaries.
• Media and Sexuality (Session 5): The curriculum encourages critical evaluation of media, including social media and advertising, focusing on their influence on body image, gender roles, and unrealistic expectations. It includes a specific activity on sexually explicit media (pornography and sexting), emphasizing the difference between fantasy and reality, and the risks involved.
• Sexual Health and Safety (Sessions 6 & 7): These sessions cover establishing and maintaining sexual consent (as an ongoing process), reviewing information on STIs and safer sex practices, and providing a demonstration of the correct use of both external and internal condoms. Session 7 covers different contraceptive methods and equips youth with knowledge of their patient rights when seeking clinical services (confidentiality, access to services without parental consent in DC, and advocating for themselves).
• Future Planning (Session 8): The final session includes a review, the post-program evaluation, and an activity where participants develop a personal health plan to integrate lessons learned into their lives, anticipating challenges and identifying support systems.
Implementation Guidance
Facilitators are provided with bolstered guidance, including scripted language to ensure fidelity and help navigate sensitive topics. They are trained to use a participatory and interactive approach (e.g., role-play, discussion, game-based learning), and are reminded of their role as mandatory reporters for disclosures of abuse or harm.

Title: Generations for Change: Engaging Men and Boys in Addressing Violence against Women and Girls (Parents’ Curriculum)
Summary:
Summary of the Source
This document is the Generations for Change – Parents Curriculum, a 13-session program jointly developed by Equimundo and Terre des hommes Lausanne (Tdh), with support from the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation. It has been specifically adapted to the Jordanian context.
Target Audience and Goals
The curriculum is designed for parents of early adolescents (ages 12 to 14). It engages both fathers and mothers to take a family approach centered on gender norms, healthy relationships, and positive parenting techniques. The core goal is to reduce intergenerational violence and foster caring and supportive relationships within the family.
Structure and Content
The curriculum is divided into thirteen sessions. A complementary curriculum exists for youth, and parents and youth participate together in two sessions toward the end. The format alternates between sessions held with men and women separately (e.g., Sessions 1–4, 7) and sessions where they engage together (starting with Session 5).
Key themes covered include:
• Gender and Norms (Session 2): Participants discuss the difference between sex and gender, reflect on how gender norms (expectations of men and women, explored through the "Man Box, Woman Box, Human Box" activity) influence lives and relationships, and explore roles in the home and society.
• Legacy and History (Session 3 & 5): Parents reflect on their own parents’ influence to reinforce positive aspects and avoid repeating harmful patterns. Session 5 brings couples together for the first time to explore their shared history and future.
• Emotions and Conflict (Session 4 & 8): Sessions help participants identify and express anger through means other than violence. Conflict resolution involves identifying sources of conflict and practicing effective communication skills, active listening, and nonviolent ways to react.
• Power and Violence (Session 6 & 7): Participants increase their awareness of power (including "power over," "power to," "power with," and "power within") and the advantages of equitable decision-making within the home. Session 7 identifies different types of violence (physical, emotional/psychological, sexual, economic) and discusses the link between past violence and violence used against others (Cycle of Violence). The curriculum stresses that violence is a learned behavior that can be unlearned.
• Parenting Adolescents (Session 9 & 10): Sessions focus on learning about adolescent development (ages 12–14), building parental empathy, and showing love and affection. Positive parenting skills and techniques are taught to discourage harsh discipline (hitting, slapping, yelling), emphasizing that aggression is counterproductive to achieving long-term goals for children.
• Family Collaboration (Session 11, 12, 13): The final sessions, including those facilitated with children present, focus on effective family communication, developing a shared family vision, reflecting on positive changes made, and creating family action plans to sustain these changes.
Facilitation and Safety
Facilitators are positioned as guides, not teachers, promoting participatory learning and critical reflection. Due to the sensitive nature of the topics, facilitators must prioritize creating a safe space, use a trauma-sensitive approach, and be knowledgeable about referral services for mental health, violence, and child protection concerns. They must also be aware of and explain mandatory reporting requirements for disclosures of abuse involving minors. The methodology uses structured elements like Mindfulness Activities and a Weekly Commitment (homework) to help participants apply lessons daily.

Title: Generations for Change: Engaging Men and Boys in Addressing Violence against Women and Girls (Youth Curriculum)
Summary:
Summary of the Source
This document is the Generations for Change – Youth Curriculum, developed by Equimundo and Terre des hommes Lausanne (Tdh), with support from the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC). Published in September 2022, it is part of an innovative program that centers a family approach to healthy relationships and gender norms.
Target Audience and Structure
The curriculum is intended to be facilitated separately with young adolescents, specifically boys and girls aged 12 to 14. Its primary goal is to reduce intergenerational violence and foster caring and supportive relationships within families. The program consists of 13 sessions, with the majority held in single-sex groups to allow participants to feel comfortable discussing sensitive issues. However, two sessions (Session 11, "Communicating as a Family," and Session 12, "My Family Working as a Team") are designed to bring the youth together with their parents.
Core Thematic Content
The curriculum guides youth through critical reflections on socialization, power, and violence:
• Gender and Norms (Sessions 2 & 3): Sessions aim to build understanding on the difference between sex and gender and reflect on how rigid gender roles and expectations (e.g., "Act Like a Man," "Act Like a Woman") impact the lives and well-being of both boys and girls.
• Power Dynamics (Session 4): Participants increase their awareness of power and its existence in relationships, including the four forms of power: power over, power to, power with, and power within. The goal is to reflect on how to use power in positive ways and avoid using others as "things".
• Violence and Empathy (Sessions 5 & 6): The curriculum identifies different types of violence (physical, emotional/psychological, sexual, and economic). Violence is defined as a learned behavior that can be eliminated. Sessions also focus on building empathy by having youth reflect on causing harm, experiencing violence, and ways to break the cycle of violence.
• Family, Emotions, and Future (Sessions 7–13): Youth reflect on the influence and legacy of their parents and authority figures to avoid repeating negative patterns. Session 8 focuses on identifying anger and emotions and teaching positive ways to express feelings without resorting to violence. Later sessions focus on developing effective communication skills with family, planning for the future, and constructing positive self-identities and life plans.
Facilitation and Safety Guidelines
Facilitators are explicitly defined as guides, not teachers, whose role is to promote critical reflection and participatory learning. The materials provide detailed guidance on creating a safe space, managing potentially difficult group dynamics (especially during mixed sessions), and using techniques like Mindfulness Activities and Weekly Commitments ("homework"). Due to the sensitive nature of the topics, facilitators must be knowledgeable about referral services for counseling and support and are reminded repeatedly of their obligations regarding mandatory reporting of abuse or sexual assault involving minors.

Title: JOURNEYS OF TRANSFORMATION DIALOGUE CLUBS: A TRAINING MANUAL FOR ENGAGING MEN AS ALLIES IN WOMEN’S ECONOMIC EMPOWERMENT
Summary:
Summary of the Source
This manual outlines the Journeys of Transformation Dialogue Clubs, a 13-session training manual developed by Equimundo: Center for Masculinities and Social Justice and Global Communities (formerly PCI). The program is financially assisted by the USDA through the EDUCAMOS project and is designed for implementation in Guatemala and across the region.
Target Audience and Goals
The program is designed to engage the husbands or partners of women participants already involved in Global Communities’ Women Empowered (WE) program. The WE program focuses on the economic, social, and political empowerment of women through self-managed savings groups.
The Dialogue Clubs program complements the existing WE curriculum by engaging men as more equitable and supportive partners in improving household well-being and women’s participation in economic activities. The sessions are highly interactive and dynamic, using participants' experiences to motivate the adoption of new, positive attitudes and behaviors, specifically focusing on strengthening communication skills to promote healthy, equitable, and nonviolent couple relationships.
Core objectives include:
• Promoting gender-equitable attitudes and support for women’s autonomy and leadership, particularly regarding decisions about their bodies, lives, and finances.
• Encouraging men to share the responsibility for childcare and domestic work.
• Strengthening effective couple communication and anger management skills to promote nonviolent relationships.
• Allowing men and women to recognize different forms of violence against women and children and discuss how violence is sustained by power imbalances and gender inequality.
• Increasing knowledge and balanced decision-making regarding sexual and reproductive health and family planning.
• Supporting couples in creating a household budget and discussing joint financial decision-making.
Structure and Themes
The manual is structured into 13 sessions (plus an introductory Session 0), organized around four core modules or themes:
1. Exploring Gender and Power (Sessions 2, 3): Includes reflecting on gender roles using the Man, Woman, and Human Boxes and challenging concepts of Patriarchy and Power.
2. Equality Inside and Outside the Home (Sessions 4–9): Focuses on changing roles, the intergenerational transmission of caregiving ("My Father’s Legacy"), couple communication and conflict resolution, sharing the care work, joint decision-making, family budgeting, and supporting women’s leadership.
3. Sexual and Reproductive Health and Family Planning (Session 10): Addresses the menstrual cycle, conception, contraceptive methods for men and women, and couples-based family planning discussions.
4. Working Together to Prevent Violence Against Women (Sessions 11–13): Focuses on recognizing the types of violence, understanding laws against violence, practicing anger management ("What Do I Do When I’m Angry?"), and creating a social support network.
Methodology and Implementation
The program uses a participatory methodology where sessions are generally two hours long. Sessions are designed for men and women together or separately, often separating them for sensitive topics (like gender, power, and violence) to ensure comfort and safety, while combining them for activities like couple communication and budgeting. A key element is the Weekly Commitment, a task participants must perform at home to integrate lessons into their daily lives.
The formative research conducted in Huehuetenango, Guatemala, revealed that both men and women desired a program to improve family relationships, strengthen communication, manage resources, and discuss sexual health. Recommendations for recruiting men include emphasizing how the group will help them achieve their household economic goals and highlighting personal and family benefits.
Facilitators are intended to be guides, not teachers, who create a safe, respectful, and nonjudgmental environment. Given the sensitive topics, the manual includes detailed guidance on establishing group agreements (including confidentiality) and a comprehensive referral protocol for victims of violence and mental health disclosures, emphasizing that facilitators are not counselors and must prioritize the safety and autonomy of survivors.

Title: Manual Programa H Bolivia: Involucrando a hombres y mujeres jóvenes por la igualdad de género
Summary:
Summary of the Source
This document is the Manual Programa H Bolivia, a detailed curriculum coordinated by Promundo—US, ECAM, and Colectivo Rebeldía. It was generously funded by the Embajada de Suecia en La Paz. This adaptation of Programa H is designed to work with young men and women in Bolivia to promote gender equality.
Context and Program Rationale
The manual acknowledges that gender inequality is sustained by cultural factors (restrictive gender norms) and structural factors (patriarchal systems). It notes that in Bolivia, relationships of power between men and women in the domestic and public spheres are asymmetrical. Bolivia has the highest prevalence of intimate partner violence (IPV) in Latin America (53.3% of women aged 15-49), and the use of violent discipline against children is common (reported by 80% of mothers and 75% of fathers surveyed). The manual asserts that engaging young men and women early in life to reflect on gender socialization and power inequalities is fundamental to promoting gender equality and reducing the intergenerational transmission of violence.
Methodology and Structure
Programa H is a gender-transformative intervention that utilizes periodic group educational sessions alongside community mobilization and campaigns to promote critical reflection on the "costs" of traditional masculinity. The methodology is activo—participativa (active-participatory), drawing on popular education and feminist pedagogy to create a safe climate for participants to share experiences, generate debate, and promote conscientization and change in gender relations, specifically challenging machismo and patriarchy. Sessions are ideally about two hours long, held weekly, over a period that supports sustained attitude and behavior change.
The manual is organized into six thematic Axes (Ejes) and a methodological framework:
1. Gender and Identity (Eje I): Includes sessions on the difference between sex and gender, and the restrictive nature of the Traditional Masculinity Box and Traditional Femininity Box.
2. Power and Relationships (Eje II): Focuses on recognizing the existence of power in relationships, the experience of being treated as "things", and the collective proposal of despatriarcalización (de-patriarchalization) to dismantle rigid power structures.
3. Sexual and Reproductive Rights (Eje III): Discusses the erotic body, the importance of sexual consent, Sexual and Reproductive Rights (DSDR), and prevention and detection of Sexually Transmitted Infections (ITS) and VIH/SIDA.
4. Care (Eje IV): Examines the legacy of the father and challenges the cultural assignment of caregiving roles solely to women, promoting the idea that care is the responsibility of both men and women.
5. Violence (Eje V): Identifies various types of violence (physical, psychological, sexual, economic), contrasts healthy and unhealthy relationships, and motivates men to become allies in action against machista violence.
6. Thinking about my future (Eje VI): Focuses on building a support network and defining a Commitment to Change regarding restrictive roles and machista expressions.
Facilitation and Safety
The facilitator acts as a guide, helping to open conversations and reflections, and must be sensitive and receptive, avoiding judgment or culpabilization. Given the sensitive topics, the manual emphasizes the construction of "Reglas de convivencia" (Rules of coexistence) and provides extensive ethical guidelines on confidentiality and specific steps for responding to and referring participants who reveal having suffered violence or who are experiencing severe mental health issues (e.g., suicidal ideation). Facilitators are reminded that they are not psychological counselors or therapists.

Title: Promoting Men’s Engagement in Early Childhood Development: A Programming and Influencing Package
Summary:
Summary of the Source
This document is a comprehensive guidance package developed for programs aiming to increase male engagement in nurturing care, early childhood development (ECD), and maternal health and wellbeing. It is based significantly on modules developed by Plan International Canada and Promundo for the Strengthening Health Outcomes for Women and Children (SHOW) project.
Core Philosophy: Gender-Transformative Approach
The guidance emphasizes a gender-transformative approach. This approach aims to tackle the root causes of gender inequality and reshape unequal gender and power relations to achieve full realization of rights for all, particularly girls and women. Promoting men's engagement in ECD is considered a crucial entry point for challenging limiting and discriminatory gender norms and roles.
A truly gender-transformative approach seeks long-term, positive changes in gender norms, relations, and power dynamics, striving to mobilize men as allies with women in promoting gender equality. It encourages critical reflection on gender roles and supports women's empowerment by addressing the distribution of resources and duties. Interventions should commit to principles like "do no harm," recognizing the potential risks of backlash or unintentionally reducing women's autonomy.
Why Men's Engagement Matters
The document presents strong evidence supporting men's positive involvement in care and development:
• For Children: Caring, non-violent male involvement is associated with positive outcomes, including better physical and mental health, higher educational achievement, better peer relationships, greater empathy, and lower rates of behavioral problems. This benefit exists regardless of whether the father resides with the child.
• For Female Partners: Engaging men during pregnancy and fatherhood addresses underlying gender inequalities that can hinder maternal health and wellbeing. It is linked to increased uptake of Maternal, Newborn, and Child Health (MNCH) services by women.
• For Men and Families: Involved men report greater life satisfaction, less stress, and are more likely to adopt health-promoting behaviors. Men's participation is linked to improved couple relationships, greater satisfaction, increased equality in decision-making, and lower rates of domestic violence.
Key Barriers to Engagement
Despite the benefits, men’s engagement in unpaid care work remains limited globally. Barriers exist at multiple levels (individual, social, material, institutional):
• Gender Norms: Men are typically expected to be the protector and provider, while caregiving and domestic chores are viewed as less valued "women's tasks". Men who defy these norms may face ridicule or shaming.
• Beliefs about Capability: There is a prevailing societal belief that men are inadequate or not biologically programmed to be good caregivers, despite research showing fatherhood produces hormonal changes that support bonding.
• Service Exclusion: Men are often passively or actively excluded from child and family services (like MNCH), as services are often not welcoming, supportive, or offered at times men can attend.
• Policy Gaps: Policy environments often lack support, such as sufficient paid, non-transferable paternity leave.
Program Framework and Strategies
The guidance uses a Socio-Ecological Model to analyze influencing factors and entry points for challenging harmful gender norms at individual, relational, community, and societal/structural levels.
Key intervention strategies outlined in the chapters include:
1. Direct Work with Men (Chapter 2): Using group education, home visits, and mentorship (like Promundo’s Program H) to foster critical reflection, dialogue, and skills-building. Groups can be men-only, women-only, or synchronized (couples' sessions).
2. Enabling Services (Chapters 3 & 4): Working with healthcare providers, Community Health Workers (CHWs), and early education staff to adapt services (e.g., offering alternative clinic hours, training staff on gender norms) so they welcome and support men's participation. This also includes efforts to increase male educators in ECCE.
3. Community and Leaders (Chapter 5): Engaging respected faith leaders and traditional leaders as key allies and "norm trend-setters" to model and endorse new positive behaviors, fostering community-wide change.
4. Policy Influencing (Chapter 6): Implementing advocacy to change laws, policies (like paternity leave or social protection), and service regulations to create an enabling environment for male engagement.
5. Social and Behaviour Change Communication (SBCC) (Chapter 7): Developing messaging (e.g., posters, media) that is positive, aspirational, and gender-transformative to influence individual attitudes and social norms, often drawing on MenCare Global Campaign best practices.

Title: Bandebereho Facilitator’s Manual: Engaging men as fathers and partners in maternal and newborn health, caregiving, violence prevention, and healthier couple relations
Summary:
Summary of the Source
This document is the Facilitator's Manual for the Bandebereho couples’ intervention, designed for expectant couples and parents of young children ages 0 to 5 in Rwanda. The program was adapted for the Rwandan context by the Rwanda Men’s Resource Center (RWAMREC), in partnership with Promundo. The current version (2021) is specifically adapted for transition-to-scale and delivery by trained community health workers via the Rwandan health system.
Program Goals and Impact
Bandebereho uses fatherhood as an entry-point to promote men’s active, non-violent, and equitable involvement in their children’s lives and family relationships. It employs a gender-transformative approach, requiring participants to critically question and reflect on rigid gender norms and social expectations for men and women, and the impact these norms have on their roles as partners and parents.
A Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT) demonstrated the program’s significant impact, including:
• Reductions in both intimate partner violence (IPV) and violence against children (VAC).
• Improved maternal and newborn health (MNCH) outcomes, such as greater antenatal care attendance by women (and accompaniment by men).
• Greater use of modern contraceptive methods.
Structure and Core Themes
The current manual includes 17 thematic sessions (up from an earlier 15-session version). Sessions are typically 2 to 3 hours long. Many sessions are designed for men and women together, promoting dialogue between partners, while some are facilitated for men only to discuss sensitive topics more comfortably. The methodology relies on participatory activities, group discussion, and homework assignments (or "check-in") to apply lessons in daily life.
Key themes covered include:
• Gender and Identity (Session 2): Discussing the difference between sex and gender and reflecting on how gender norms influence expectations of men and women.
• Health and Caregiving (Sessions 4–7): Informing couples about healthy pregnancy, preparing men to support their partners during birth, including pain alleviation techniques, and promoting skin-to-skin contact for bonding and ensuring newborn care needs.
• Parenting and Violence (Sessions 8, 10–12): Connecting long-term goals for children (ages 0-5) with positive parenting skills, reflecting on the intergenerational impact of parents, identifying different types of violence (physical, emotional, sexual, economic), and discussing how to break the cycle of violence.
• Couple and Family Relations (Sessions 13–16): Reflecting on power dynamics and the advantages of equitable decision-making, encouraging men's participation in sharing household responsibilities (care work/housework), learning non-violent conflict resolution and communication techniques, and addressing the consequences of alcohol and drug abuse.
• Future Planning (Sessions 9, 14, 17): Reflecting on the benefits of family planning/contraception, creating a shared family vision, discussing family finances/budgeting, and creating family action plans to sustain positive changes.
Facilitation
Facilitators (ideally a male and a female pair) act as guides who encourage self-reflection and participation, rather than teachers. They must create a safe space and be prepared to manage sensitive topics, promoting inclusion of all participants, including those with disabilities, and be knowledgeable about referral services for professional support or counseling

Title: Recruitment and Retention of Male Participants in Gender-Transformative Programs.
Summary:
Summary of the Source
This brief, authored by Promundo and Plan International Canada, summarizes programmatic lessons and best practices for effectively recruiting and retaining male participants in gender-transformative programs. It draws on experiences from various global settings, including the multi-country Strengthening Health Outcomes for Women and Children (SHOW) program, which was funded by Global Affairs Canada.
Program Rationale (Why Engage Men)
The brief emphasizes that engaging men is crucial for achieving gender equality and improving family well-being. Male engagement is defined as men taking an active role in protecting and promoting the health and well-being of their partners and children, premised on a vision of sustainable behavioral and relational change.
• Benefits: Involved fatherhood benefits children's physical and mental health. Men themselves experience improvements in physical, mental, and sexual health outcomes, along with reductions in risk-taking behaviors. Programs like the SHOW project's Fathers Clubs promote men's equitable and nonviolent involvement in Maternal, Newborn, and Child Health (MNCH) and Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR).
• Entry Points: Expectant and new fatherhood is highlighted as an especially effective, transformative entry point for engaging men. Many men desire stronger emotional relationships and want to learn nonviolent ways to resolve conflict and discipline children, making them potential powerful agents of intergenerational change.
Common Barriers to Recruitment and Retention
Despite the benefits, programs often face challenges rooted in norms and economic constraints.
• Restrictive Gender Norms: Prevailing concepts of "good fatherhood" often revolve only around the roles of "protector" and "provider," without emphasizing the role of "nurturer". If men feel they already live up to societal expectations, they may not see a need to participate in programming that promotes more involved fatherhood.
• Economic Constraints: In many contexts, conflicting work schedules or the need to attend to daily income-generating activities (especially agriculture in rural areas) prevent regular attendance.
• Backlash: Participants may face criticism or "backbiting" from within their households or the broader community for challenging norms or attending the sessions, which can act as a deterrent.
Best Practices and Lessons Learned
The brief details effective strategies based on field experiences (e.g., in Rwanda's Bandebereho program, and various SHOW countries):
• Scheduling and Logistics: Programs must meet men where they are—metaphorically and literally—by ensuring accessible physical venues. Scheduling sessions for the evenings or weekends and avoiding high-demand seasons (like harvesting) is recommended to accommodate work schedules.
• Messaging and Approach: Recruitment must appeal to men’s aspirations as fathers and partners. Programs should use a strengths-based approach and frame gender equality as not just a women's issue but one that benefits men's relationships, health, and lives.
• Content Implementation: Difficult topics like power and gender inequality should be introduced gradually to prevent men from feeling defensive or stigmatized. It is essential to clarify that participants are not being targeted or punished for "bad" behaviors.
• Community Integration: Engaging influential community leaders and faith leaders can increase program acceptance and uptake. However, this requires careful management to ensure the program remains gender-transformative rather than becoming merely gender-accommodating. Concurrent Social and Behavior Change Communication (SBCC) campaigns can help create a broader enabling environment that supports men's engagement.
• Retention Strategies: Strategies include providing simple amenities (e.g., snacks), using non-monetary incentives like awards, incorporating engaging methods like homework/discussions and role-play, and planning "family days" to engage the entire household.

Title: ole of Facilitation in Gender-Transformative Programs That Engage Men and Boys.
Summary:
Summary of the Source
This document is a brief authored by Promundo and Plan International Canada that summarizes programmatic lessons and best practices regarding high-quality facilitation within gender-transformative programs that engage men and boys. The brief draws on experiences from diverse global settings, including the Strengthening Health Outcomes for Women and Children (SHOW) program implemented across countries such as Bangladesh, Ghana, Haiti, Nigeria, and Senegal, as well as programs in Tajikistan, Nepal, Rwanda, and the United States.
The Importance of Facilitation and Critical Consciousness
Skilled facilitators are considered essential to the success of gender-transformative programs, as high-quality facilitation is vital for achieving program objectives and initiating transformative change. Effective group interventions aim to foster critical consciousness—an understanding of how social conditions privilege some but not others—by encouraging reflection on personal experiences, building group solidarity, and committing to making changes. Programs achieve this by starting a process of critical reflection and building solidarity among group members to mobilize change. For example, Promundo’s approach often includes exercises where men listen to women’s experiences regarding the unequal caregiving load or workplace discrimination, which can ignite critical consciousness when guided by a skilled facilitator.
Key Differences: Facilitator vs. Teacher
The brief emphasizes that facilitators must differ fundamentally from traditional teachers.
• A teacher is typically an expert who is expected to have all the answers.
• A facilitator is a guide who need not have all the answers but instead creates an open and safe space to facilitate dialogue and critical reflection among participants. They achieve this by asking unbiased, open-ended questions to elicit reflective responses.
Best Practices for Facilitation Success
The brief outlines best practices across four key areas:
1. Selection of Facilitators: Facilitators should possess strong interpersonal skills (e.g., authenticity, emotional maturity, active listening, ability to guide discussions). Recruitment should cast a wide net, and screening may include role-plays to check for necessary "soft skills". Identifying candidates from feminist and progressive social justice organizations is a good starting point as they often already embody the participatory values of gender-transformative programs. Facilitators should ideally be familiar with and able to relate to the participants' lived realities to build trust. Demographics like age and marital status may need consideration due to cultural norms affecting group dynamics.
2. Training: Training must provide sufficient time and intensity; training periods ranging from ten days up to 25 days (including booster sessions) are suggested, depending on prior experience. Trainings should cover content like gender as a social construct, power, and violence against women, and allow adequate time to practice facilitation skills, learn to respond to disclosures of violence and trauma, and build group cohesion. Discussing the theoretical basis for choosing a participatory approach (e.g., Freire’s "banking" versus "liberating" models) can help prevent facilitators from reverting to authoritarian or lecture-style methods. Involving facilitators in curriculum design can build buy-in and ensure the curriculum is low-literacy friendly, if needed.
3. Facilitation Strategies: Facilitators should model gender-equitable relationships (e.g., co-facilitators sharing note-taking and leading sessions equally). They must minimize power differentials with participants, even through small gestures like sitting on the same level. Strategies include probing the group’s views rather than imposing views or giving "right" answers, and ensuring the discussion is not dominated by "gatekeepers". Sensitive topics, like violence, need adequate time and should be introduced in a generalized way, ensuring participants are never forced to share uncomfortable experiences. While empathy is a powerful tool, facilitators must be careful not to reinforce harmful gender stereotypes (e.g., valorizing women as inherently more emotional).
4. Support and Monitoring: A clear supervisory process must be established from the program's design phase. Monitoring should track implementation quality and fidelity. Supportive supervision and regular check-ins are crucial, potentially using technology like voice-recognition software for reports or social media groups (e.g., WhatsApp) for real-time troubleshooting. Programs must actively monitor against the perpetuation of harmful ideas (e.g., that violence is "provoked"). Programs should also create spaces for facilitators to reflect and recuperate (e.g., reflection diaries) to maintain motivation, as the work is intensive and demanding. Importantly, facilitators often experience deep personal change, becoming aware of unequal relationships and desiring to be more gender-equitable in their own lives.

Title: Engaging Religious Leaders in Reducing Maternal and Child Mortality, and Gender Equality: Field Experiences from the SHOW Project in Sokoto State, Nigeria
Summary:
Summary of the Source
This knowledge brief documents the programmatic benefits, challenges, and outcomes of intensely engaging Islamic religious leaders in Sokoto State, Nigeria, as part of the 4.5-year Strengthening Health Outcomes for Women and Children (SHOW) project. Sokoto State is a conservative region where 95% of the population is Muslim, and religious leaders are seen as key role models and gatekeepers of social values and behaviors.
Program Rationale and Approach
The SHOW project aimed to reduce maternal and child mortality by taking a gender-transformative approach. This involved empowering women and girls, engaging men to address rigid gender-related barriers, and improving the quality and use of Maternal, Newborn, and Child Health (MNCH) and Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR) services. Engaging religious leaders was seen as crucial to creating an enabling environment for successful male engagement and promoting gender-equitable relationships.
Key Activities and Methodology
The program engaged religious leaders through several sequential activities:
1. Sensitization Meetings: Highly interactive meetings where health officials presented data on maternal and child mortality, and religious leaders discussed harmful practices, decision-making in the family, and the importance of supporting pregnant and breastfeeding mothers.
2. Training of Trainers (ToT): Promundo conducted a ToT on the Fathers Clubs manual (adapted from Program P), a curriculum designed to engage fathers in gender equality, MNCH, and SRHR.
3. Co-creation of the Manual: The most innovative strategy was the co-creation and validation of the “Islamic Perspectives on MNCH Issues” manual. This document, led by Sheikh (Dr.) Mustapha Sidi Attahiru, provides evidence from the Quran and Hadith showing that messages on gender equality, supporting wives, and practices like child spacing are compatible with or even required by Islam. This process built strong ownership among the religious community.
Findings and Impact
The research, which relied on interviews with religious leaders and Plan staff (but lacked interviews with community members), documented several successes:
• Gender and Health Messaging: Religious leaders used the manual as a reference to consistently share gender-equitable MNCH/SRH messages during weekly Friday sermons in the mosque, as well as on radio and TV shows and at ceremonies (like Ramadan and weddings). Linking these messages directly to the Quran helped prevent community backlash because religious texts are viewed as absolute truth.
• Attitude Change: The intensive engagement and collaboration process led to considerable shifts in the personal attitudes and practices of the religious leaders themselves. Male leaders started acting as role models by helping their wives with household chores (cooking, sweeping) and escorting them to the clinic.
• Community and Household Changes (Reported by Leaders): Religious leaders reported positive community changes, including men sharing decision-making power in the household, increased women's participation in community work committees and small businesses, and men routinely participating in household chores even when their wives were not sick. Mosques reportedly became safe spaces for men to discuss sensitive MNCH issues.
Challenges and Lessons Learned
Challenges included achieving consensus on the interpretation of the Quran during the manual’s creation, especially regarding child spacing. Other challenges were logistical, such as the fact that female religious leaders could not use the mosque for consistent preaching, and the difficulty of reaching older audiences. A key lesson learned was that replacing the phrase "family planning" with "child spacing" (and linking it to the Hadith) made the topic more acceptable to followers.
